greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number A(n,k) of lattice paths without interior points from {n}^k to {0}^k using steps that decrement one component by 1; square array A(n,k), n>=0, k>=0, read by antidiagonals.
comment: An interior point p = (p_1, ..., p_k) has k>0 components with 0<p_i<n for 1<=i<=k.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..20, flattened
example: A(2,1) = 0, there is no path from (2) to (0) without interior points.
maple: b:= proc(n, l) option remember; local m; m:= nops(l);
mathematica: b[n_, l_] := b[n, l] = With[{m = Length[l]}, If[m == 0 || l[[m]] == 0, 1, If[l[[1]] > 0 && l[[m]] < n, 0, Sum[If[l[[i]] == 0, 0, b[n, Sort[ReplacePart[l, i -> l[[i]] - 1]]]], {i, 1, m}]]] ]; a[n_, k_] := b[n, Array[n&, k]]; Table[Table[a[n, d-n], {n, 0, d}], {d, 0, 10}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 16 2013, translated from Maple *)
xref: Cf. A089759 (unrestricted paths), A210472, A262809, A263159.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Apr 27 2013
